ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Confidence on the lab bench, confidence giving talks and presentations!
research techniques in protein purification and analysis like centrifugation, precipitation and isolation via acid/dialysis/sucrose gradient, and gels, and background on how techniques work

This is an experiments-driven course that teaches students how to think creatively in the context of real research problems. I learned basic wet lab techniques such as SDS-PAGE, immunoblotting, PCR, column chromatography, etc. I also learned how to present research papers through 15-min and 30-min job talks.

Learned extensively about COVID, microscopy, differential centrifugation, and size-exclusion chromatography, among other topics. The course goes into great detail on these areas, preparing students well for future lab work while also honing their ability to work effectively in a lab environment and giving scientific presentations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was amazing! The experiments we performed improved my understanding of cell bio. Prof. Wolenski really cares about his students and wanted us to have fun. Life is good!

only strengths!!! having a COVID-19 safe lab was the only in-person class experience I had this semester, and I was very grateful for the welcoming environment in this lab every Mon & Wed. Having little cell biology wet-lab experience going in, I also appreciated the hands-on learning in each experiment for each student, and the ability to improve as the course progressed

The best STEM course I've ever taken!  The strength of this course lies completely in Professor Wolenski. The amount of thought, care, and knowledge he imparts to this lab and to his students is unmatched.

The greatest strength of this course is the instructor, Prof. Wolenski. He is deeply engaged during class, and provides individual feedback to each of his students. This class is definitely designed for both experienced and inexperienced students, and teamwork is facilitated by the nature of the class's designstudents are expected to work collaboratively and help each other when needed. If there was one weakness I had to list, it would be that sometimes the procedure of experiments was not comprehensively explained. However, this was a rare occurrence and likely due to last-minute changes the instructors had to make because of Covid-19 complications.

This course is taught wonderfully. It fosters a collaborative learning environment that the vast majority of Yale courses lack. You will learn loads. My only recommendation would be that it would be nice to receive written feedback on our presentations. Take the course if you can--but apply early! Email Prof Wolenski ASAP.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly, I was just thankful to be able to have an in-person class. I think it went as great as it could!
COVID-19 safety via masks and distancing were very successful; in-person lab learning really simulated what conducting our own experiments would be like

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes definitely take this class if you are able to! Email Wolenski ASAP cause that is your only chance at getting in. Labs can be long but everyone in the class got very close despite the pandemic. It was an amazing opportunity to learn fundamental lab techniques and we got to give presentations ("job talks") to deepen our understanding of course themes.
Definitely! I emailed Prof. Wolenski in 2018 for this class which I took in 2021. Never too early to send him an email to express your interest!!

absolutely!!! this class really became my family over the course of the semester; we were able to learn and laugh while at it. looked forward to every Mon & Wed, best class i've taken at yale so far, and will be memorable for years to come. the techniques we learned will prepare me very well for detailed wet-lab work for senior year. make sure to send an email to prof. wolenski by summer after first-year to have a spot!

Yes, wholeheartedly! A phenomenal course taught by one of, if not, the best professor I've had at Yale. Professor Wolenski's engagement with his class surpasses every single expectation. The whole course is geared towards helping you develop the skills needed to become a better scientist, and you'll have the most inspiring guide and most supportive community while doing so.

This is hands-down the best class I have taken at Yale, and probably the best lab course in the MCDB department. I'd definitely recommend this class to any student considering doing independent research or pursuing research as a career or graduate school option. Just be sure to apply early (by emailing Prof. Wolenski) during your first year to secure a spot during your junior year.

Taking this course was one of the best decisions I've made. If you are lucky enough to get a spot (email early!!) you will not regret taking it. It's a wonderful way to learn cell biology, meet friends, and have a wonderful and close experience with a kind and thoughtful professor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We were on zoom for the first two sessions

We had seminars over Zoom for the first two weeks of class, when we were not permitted to enter Yale buildings due to mandatory quarantine. These lectures were on SARS-CoV-2 biology, treatments, and vaccines.
